prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Line flux estimate: The [CII] 158 micron line has a flux of about 9.6e-18 W/m2 for this source. The [CI] 370 micron line should be about 1% of [CII] 158 micron line. So the expected flux is 9.6e-20 W/m2 or 9.6e-17 erg/cm2/s. Based on HIFI [CII] line observations, line width is 340 km/s (FWHM), corresponding to 281 MHz at the redshifted frequency of [CI] 370 micron. So the expected flux density would be 9.6e-17 erg/cm2/s / 281 MHz = 34 mJy.
For this object, uniquely among our sample, we have a weak (~ 3 sigma) detection of the [CI] 2-1 line from the IRAM 30m telescope. The observed peak flux is 24 mJy, which we use in our exposure time calculations. The much higher signal-to-noise expected from ALMA will be invaluable in kinematic fitting of this source.
We request sufficient integration time to achieve 1 mJy noise after 20 km/s binning. For this object, this integration time should suffice to not only detect the [CI] 370 micron line at high SNR, but also to detect the CO 7-6 transition and the 752.033 GHz water line. We use TDM for the water line and for the fourth baseband, which we dedicate to continuum measurements, while we use FDM for the [CI] and CO lines, where finer spectral resolution is potentially useful.
The largest spatial structure of interest in the source is 8 arcseconds.
The continuum flux density, extrapolated from the SPIRE 500 micron measurement to 1.3mm using a grey body spectrum, is about 35 mJy.

Flux estimate: The [CII] 158 micron line has a flux of about 3e-18 W/m2 for this source. The [CI] 370 micron line should be about 1% of [CII] 158 micron line. So expected flux is 3e-20 W/m2 or 3e-17 erg/cm2/s. The line width from the [CII] observations is 325 km/s. This corresponds to 260 MHz at the redshifted frequency of [CI] 370 micron. So the expected flux density is 3e-17 erg/cm2/s / 259 MHz = 11 mJy.
We request sufficient integration time to achieve 1 mJy noise in 20 km/s bins. For this source, the resulting signal-to-noise ratio should be SNR=11 in each of 16 bins across the line, allowing kinematic modeling of the emission line. It also provides good insurance against the possibility that the CI / CII line flux ratio is low. The aggregate s/n on the line would be 5 for the case of an 0.1% line flux ratio.
We use FDM for the [CI] and CO 7-6 lines, and TDM for the remaining two basebands, which sample a water line and the continuum.
The spatial structure of the lensed arc here is a nearly complete annulus with inner and outer radii of about 4" and 5" respectively, so that the largest scale of interest is the 10" outer diameter.
The continuum flux density, extrapolated as a grey body from the SPIRE 500 micron measurement, is expected to be about 1.6 mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SMM J14011: [CI] line
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: SMM J14011: [CI] 370 micron line observations. [Source also called Abell 1835a]

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Flux estimate: The [CII] 158 micron line has a flux of about 1.75e-18 W/m2 for this source. The [CI] 370 micron line should be about 1% of [CII] 158 micron line. So the expected flux is 1.75e-20 W/m2 or 1.75e-17 erg/cm2/s. The estimated line width is 240 km/s (FWHM), corresponding to 181 MHz at the redshifted frequency of [CI] 370 micron. So the expected flux density is 1.75e-17 erg/cm2/s / 181 MHz = 9.7 mJy.
We request sufficient integration time to achieve a 1 mJy noise level in 20 km/s bins. This corresponds to s/n = 10 in 12 bins across the line, allowing kinematic modeling of the galaxy. We also have good insurance against low [CI]/[CII] ratios; we would expect a solid detection of the [CI] line with SNR>5 for any line flux ratio down to 0.15%.
Spatial structure: Ivison et al shows a compact source in both O/IR and VLA images, with the largest scale of interest being 3 arcseconds.
Continuum flux density: We take this from the published flux density at 1.35 mm from Ivison et al.

Flux estimate: The [CII] 158 micron line has a flux of 9.8e-19 W/m2 for this source. The [CI] 370 micron line should be about 1% of [CII] 158 micron line. So the expected flux is 9.8e-21 W/m2 or 9.8e-18 erg/cm2/s. The [CII] line width of 195 km/s (FWHM), which corresponds to 141 MHz at the redshifted frequency of [CI] 370 micron. So the expected flux density is 9.8e-18 erg/cm2/s / 141 MHz = 7 mJy.
We request sufficient integration time to reach a noise level of 1 mJy in 20 km/s channels. This should yield a typical SNR=7 per bin for 10 bins across the emission line, enabling kinematic modeling of the source. If the CI/CII line flux ratio is lower than expected, down to 0.2%, we should still get an adequate CI flux ratio to model physical conditions in the emitting gas.
Here we have two basebands on lines (CI and CO 7-6), using FDM mode, and two basebands on the continuum, using TDM mode.
Spatial structure: This arc has a longest dimension of 8 arcseconds, and a width of about 1 arcsecond.
Continuum: We extrapolate the continuum flux density from that observed in the SPIRE data at 500 microns, using a grey body slope. We find an expected continuum flux density of 18 mJy.

Flux estimate: THe [CII] 158 micron line has a flux of about 2e-18 W/m2 for this source. The [CI] 370 micron line should be about 1% of [CII] 158 micron line. So the expected flux is 2e-20 W/m2 or 2e-17 erg/cm2/s. The observed CII line width is 296 km/s (FWHM), corresponding to 215 MHz at the redshifted frequency of [CI] 370 micron. So the expected [CI] flux density is 2e-17 erg/cm2/s / 215 MHz = 9.3 mJy.
We request sufficient integration time to achieve a 1mJy noise level in 20 km/s bins. This corresponds to s/n = 9.3 per bin, with 15 bins across the line. This is sufficient to enable kinematic modeling of the lensed galaxy, or alternatively to ensure a CI line detection with SNR>5 provided that the line flux ratio (CI / CII) is at least 1.4%.
The spatial structure of the lensed source is compact, about 4 arcseconds.
The continuum flux density is estimated by extrapolating the SPIRE 500 micron fluxes to 1.3 mm using a grey body curve. This yields an expected continuum flux density around 6 mJy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We request 3.3 hours of band 6 time to observe [CI] (2-1) and CO (7-6) lines in 5 extremely lensed, but otherwise typical star-forming galaxies at redshifts z=2-3. These galaxies are part of our survey of [CII](158 micron) and [OI] (63 micron) lines with Herschel (the Herschel Extreme Lensing Line Observations 'HELLO'). The HELLO sample of normal galaxies forms an ideal complement to studies of dusty starbursts at z=2.
Our propsed ALMA observations reach interesting limits of [CI](2-1)/FIR = 10^{-5.5} in 40 minutes (with overheads) per galaxy. In 2 cases, we will also detect the H2O 2(1,1)-2(0,2) line.
Combined with the Herschel [CII] line measurements, the [CI] and CO lines will give a complete picture of the physical conditions, including density, far-ultraviolet flux, temperature, and pressures in atomic and molecular gas. With the [CII], [OI], [CI], and multiple CO lines we will have the total cooling budget and we can determine whether their ISM at z=2 is fundamentally different from the local universe. ALMA's spatial resolution will also allow a study of spatially resolved kinematics of these galaxies, among which some show outflows and some show cold rotation.
